ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GOLF COURSES IN FOREST RESERVES


    1. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry has any intention of building golf courses in our forest reserves.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member is probably referring to the Public Utilities Board's (PUB) proposal to develop a golf course at the Lower Peirce Reservoir. This is still at a very preliminary stage as PUB has not submitted it to the Chief Planner for planning approval. The

Column: 104

PUB has commissioned an "environmental impact study" to determine the impact of the project on the ecology of the area. If the study shows that the golf course will cause extensive damage to the nature reserves, it is unlikely that the Chief Planner will approve it.

    I would like to assure the House that my Ministry is as aware as anybody else of the need to protect our nature reserves. Despite our limited land resource, we have set aside some 2,000 hectares of land in the Central Catchment and Bukit Timah areas as gazetted Nature Reserves.

    Currently, the National Parks Board is conducting a physical and biological survey of the nature reserves. This survey will provide National Parks Board with a comprehensive data base on the reserves' physical features and animal and plant life. The survey findings will be used to identify and preserve core areas with the richest concentration of animal and plant life. Through proper planning, National Parks Board can tap the full potential of our nature reserves for educational and recreational use with minimal impact on areas of greatest ecological value.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, which organisation has been commissioned to undertake the "environmental impact study" and what are their credentials?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot recollect the name of the person who has been engaged by the PUB. There are two studies going on. One is the PUB study on the impact of the proposed golf course and, I mentioned the other study that is being done by the National Parks Board. I cannot tell the Member the name but obviously before they were selected we went through their qualifications. If the Member wants, I can supply him the name later.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Speaker, Sir, if this project is still in the proposal stage, why is it that an announcement has been made and this has created so much anxiety among certain Singaporeans?

Column: 105



     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps the word "proposal" that I used is not quite the right word. It is an idea that the PUB is looking into. I do not know who made the announcement and how it came out in the press. Certainly no announcement was made by my Ministry or by the Planning Department. But somehow the subject emerged in the media and, of course, nature lovers jumped on it and blew it up into a big matter. But as I mentioned just now, no planning application has been made yet and when it is made, it will be considered in the usual way.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
PURCHASED FLATS
(Demand and waiting period)


    2. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether the demand for bigger Housing and Development Board purchased flats increased significantly in 1990 and 1991 and what further steps are being taken to reduce the waiting period for such flats under the new booking system.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, demand for all categories of HDB flats has increased in recent years. In 1989, HDB received a total of 32,800 new applications for 4-room and larger flats. The number of applications increased to 35,100 in 1990 and 48,200 in 1991, an increase of 47% over the three-year period. This increase is due to the increasing number of applicants who are upgrading to bigger flats.

    Demand for 5-room flats was especially buoyant, with the number of applications for 5-room flats nearly doubling over the last three years, from 10,100 in 1989, to 11,300 in 1990, and 19,200 in 1991. Over the same period, demand for Executive flats also rose but at a lower rate of about 26%. There were 7,400 applications in 1989 for Executive flats, 8,200 in 1990, and 9,300 in 1991.

    HDB has therefore stepped up its Construction Programme for new flats over the past three years. But such increase in construction is constrained by the capacity

Column: 106

of the construction industry as a whole. It has to be done gradually so as to maintain quality and not overheat the construction industry and push up building costs.

    To reduce the waiting period for certain groups of flat applicants, the balloting system for allocation of flats was modified at the beginning of this year to give priority in the allocation of flats to:

    (i) new households, in preference to upgraders; and

    (ii) repeatedly unsuccessful applicants, in preference to first-time applicants.

    Following this change, new households who apply for 5-room and Executive flats in new towns under development such as Woodlands, Chua Chu Kang and Jurong West, are generally able to book a flat after two to three ballots, ie, about six to nine months from first application. As demand for flats in Tampines New Town is relatively high, those who apply for 5-room and Executive flats in Tampines may have to wait a little longer. Generally, they should be able to book a flat after three to four ballots.

    As the Revised Balloting Scheme was implemented only recently and is working satisfactorily, it would be premature to modify it further. HDB will continue to monitor demand for HDB flats and will step up its Construction Programme for new flats as much as possible, to further reduce the waiting period for applicants.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister two supplementary questions? Is the current new booking system working better than the old system? Are there plans to address the concern about increasing prices of HDB flats?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not want to go into all the advantages of the new booking system over the old waiting list system. The system is working well and people know at the time of application whether they are going to get a flat within a very specific period. Under the old system, they just put their names there and they did not know when they were going to be offered, where they were going to be offered, and what price they

Column: 107

were going to be offered. All these uncertainties are removed in the new booking system. My view is that it is a better system, both from the point of view of the buyer as well as from the point of view of HDB which has to build these flats. It has got a better idea as to what to build and where to build these flats.

    Increasing prices of HDB flats, yes, some concern has been expressed. But I think it is very important for Members to inform their constituents and the general public that when we talk of changes in the prices of HDB flats over a period of time, and when people talk of a 4-room flat going up by 20-30% in price, we are not talking about the same product or the same type of flat. HDB is not like McDonald's. You can go to any McDonald in Singapore, it is the same Big Mac that you are going to get, the price is the same and I assume that what you buy today will be the same as what you buy a month or a year from now.

    Each HDB development is different It is in a different location, it has got a different orientation and it has got a different design. So you cannot compare, say, a 4-room flat built one year ago in Chua Chu Kang with a 4-room flat offered now in Tampines. They are not the same thing. Just as people would not compare developments in the private sector over different periods and in different places, I think people must get used to the idea that HDB is now building flats which are different. Every contract is virtually different because it takes into account location and builds in improvements that the HDB has tried out. In spite of the increased prices, it is very clear from the applications that people do value location and design and are prepared to pay for it.

    When we compare the general increase in prices, we tend to lump together all the flats offered in a quarter. Many of the flats offered may be in the city area and the prices here are high. They can be as much as one-third more than similar size flats in the outlying new towns. In spite of that, applications are also high. In the mature

Column: 108

estates, for example, in Queenstown and Geylang, for every flat there are almost seven applicants. In other words, the total number of applications was seven times the number of flats that we offered in spite of the fact that the prices were about one-third more than elsewhere.

    As regards design, Members are aware that in the last quarter, we offered, for the first time, flats designed by private architects and built by contractors for the HDB. These prices were about 15% higher than the HDB-designed flats. Yet the applications were 18 1/2 times more than the number of flats offered. So people are prepared to pay for design. But if we get the feedback that people do not want better design or good locations, then of course HDB can go back to smaller flats, cheaper designs and poorer finishes. If people want that and that is the kind of feedback we get from the demand pattern, then we will go down to building such flats.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister agree that the price of public housing should be kept at a level which is affordable to Singaporeans?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is obviously one of the main considerations - whatever we build, whatever improvements and designs we provide in HDB flats should be within the affordability of Singaporeans. We constantly keep track of this and if the Member had looked at an article in the Business Times of 16th July, which is based on some facts given by the HDB, he would have noted that in spite of the increased price, the monthly income required to afford these flats - calculated on the basis of their CPF contributions - is, in fact, still much less than the average monthly household income. So affordability is an important criterion. We try to make sure that flats are built and priced in such a way that they continue to be affordable to Singaporeans. But what we cannot do is to build flats and price them in such a way that everybody can afford an Executive flat. That is not possible. There are 3-room, 4-room, 5-room and Executive flats. We

Column: 109

provide the whole range. People must choose the flat that they can afford. We cannot promise to build the biggest flats in the best area and make them affordable to all Singaporeans.

WET MARKETS
(Selling of stalls to existing stallholders)


    3. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for the Environment whether the Government has any plans to sell the stalls in some selected wet markets to the existing stallholders.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, Government's policy is to divest itself from the management of markets and food centres over time. My Ministry is now studying the option for divestment. One option is to allow existing stallholders to buy over the stalls on a term lease in markets and food centres not affected by redevelopment and details are now being looked into.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, does the Government have any plan for the empty stalls in the wet market at Cuppage Centre and Cambridge Road market?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, Cuppage Road Market is situated in Cuppage Centre which is owned by Pidemco Land. As far as I know, Pidemco Land has plans to redevelop the site. I am sorry I do not know the details of the redevelopment plan.

    As regards Cambridge Road Market, it belongs to HDB and, as far as we know, the market will not be affected by any future redevelopment. As such, it will come under this scheme.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister when the existing stallholders would be offered the option to buy over the stalls, as the Ministry has taken a long time over this matter.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Yes, Sir, we have taken a long time because we do not want to rush into it, without considering all the

Column: 110

issues concerned. Mr Speaker, Sir, in any policy or proposal affecting stallholders, careful consideration will have to be given to minimise the displacement of hawkers and, where possible, every opportunity will be given for them to continue their trade. That is the reason why, admittedly, we have taken a long time on this matter.

Column: 110

DRUG REHABILITATION CENTRES AND PRISONS
(Number of Muslim Religious Teachers-cum-Counsellors)


    4. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs how many permanent Muslim Religious Teachers-cum-Counsellors are attached to drug rehabilitation centres and prisons, and when the required number of such Teachers-cum-Counsellors will be reached.

     The Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are three posts of Muslim Religious Teachers-cum-Counsellors in Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS). Two of the posts have been filled. One Religious Teacher-cum-Counsellor is attached full-time at Selarang Park Centre and the other at Sembawang Centre.

    MUIS has invited applications to fill the third vacant post but so far has not been able to recruit any suitable candidate. MUIS will shortly invite applications again to fill the vacancy.

ORGANISATIONS SETTING UP POLITICALLY MOTIVATED EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES


    5. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Education whether he allows organisations to set up educational facilities, such as kindergartens, whose objectives are not purely educational but are also politically motivated.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Education Act, my Ministry will allow an organisation to register and set up a school

Column: 111

provided it satisfies certain conditions. Generally, the requirements relate to the reliability and capability of the organisation and its management, the provision of safe and adequate premises for the school, the qualifications of the staff, and the school curriculum. The school has also to ensure that its activities are not detrimental to the public or the pupils.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): I am certain that the Minister did hear the announcement of the Prime Minister at the last General Election that if the constituency did not support the PAP the kindergarten will be closed. Does the Minister, in fact, view that as using the kindergarten set up by the PAP Foundation as a political tool of the Party?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, I believe that the kindergartens referred to are those run by the PAP Community Foundation, not by the PAP. The PAP Community Foundation (PCF) is a charitable organisation to promote the welfare and interest of Singaporeans. One of its objectives is to foster, develop and improve education of all kinds, including the organising and running of kindergarten classes.

    As to whether the PCF will cut back on the numbers of students in certain sectors, it is up to the PCF to decide, based on their own resource constraints and their planning. It has nothing to do with the Government.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am afraid the Minister has not answered my question. It is a clear-cut case and it is known to the public. He can look up the Straits Times of 31st August 1991, and it was stated that if the constituents did not vote PAP, the kindergartens will be cut back. That is a clear-cut case of using educational facilities for a political purpose. Does the Minister agree with me on that point first?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: To my knowledge, there was a recent announcement that the PCF has to cut back the kindergartens to some extent in certain wards. This was because of resource constraints. Anyway, the question should be properly directed to

Column: 112

the PCF because it is a matter for PCF to decide.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: No, I am asking the Minister, from what the public knows, from what the public has seen in the papers, are the facilities of the PCF being used for a political purpose? I am asking him that now, yes or no?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, I believe Mr Goh Chok Tong was speaking in his capacity as the Leader of the PAP. Of course, the PAP is the one that set up the PCF. But the PCF will have to decide what are its plans, in view of its resource constraints.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I will ask the Minister now, from what he knows, from what he reads in the papers of 31st August 1991, does he view that announcement of cutting back on the kindergarten facilities in Opposition wards if they should vote Opposition members as a political announcement? Does he not agree on that?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: I think whether it is a political issue or not is a matter of opinion.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Do not evade the question.

     Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Chiam, would you allow the Minister to complete his answer?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: It is a point of order, Sir. The Minister refuses to answer the question. It is very simple. He can give a "Yes" or a "No". But he is skirting around and refusing to answer the question.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, what is your supplementary question?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: It is very simple. I am asking him whether or not the announcement by the Prime Minister on 31st August 1991 that constituencies that vote Opposition MPs will have their kindergarten facilities cut back - and everybody knows about that - is a political one. I am asking the Minister whether or not the educational facilities of the PCF have been used for a political purpose. Yes or no? Do not skirt the question.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: It is still a matter of opinion. I think this was done during an election campaign. The PAP had the right to tell the public at that time that if they

Column: 113

elect an Opposition Member, then obviously they cannot expect the PAP MP to serve them in the same way. If the PCF is set up by the PAP, obviously it must look after the interests of its founders first.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Just now the Minister mentioned that the PAP Community Foundation is different from the PAP.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Low, are you asking a question?

     The Leader of the House (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Point of order, Mr Speaker. I think Mr Chiam is asking a question about the PCF. The Minister for Education is not in charge of the PCF. He should direct his question to the PCF.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, may I answer the Minister on that point?

     Mr Speaker: No, you are supposed to ask supplementary questions only.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is the Minister above Standing Orders?

     Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Chiam, this is not a debate. This is Question Time.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, is the Minister above Standing Orders? He stood up to clarify a point and I think the Opposition has the right to answer that point. Otherwise, it will be seen as if he is right and we are wrong.

     Mr Speaker: During Question Time, the Member has the right to ask questions.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: But he did not ask question. He clarified the point.

     Mr Speaker: He rose on a point of order. Could both of you resume your seats?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: All right, I will ask a supplementary question.

     Mr Speaker: Yes, ask your supplementary question.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I will ask the Minister for Education whether or not the kindergartens set up by the PCF is under his jurisdiction.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The answer is a clear no. The Ministry is responsible for approving and registering schools and education centres. But the kindergartens of the PCF are run by the PCF. So his question should really be directed to the PCF.

Column: 114



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Are the kindergartens of the PCF set up under the Education Act?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Yes, the kindergartens of the PCF are approved by my Ministry under the Education Act.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: If the kindergartens of the PCF are set up under the Education Act, are not these educational facilities then under your jurisdiction? Because you do supervise all educational facilities set up under the Education Act.

     The Minister for Law and Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Sir, may I raise a point of order because there are so many other Questions and, in the interest of the despatch of parliamentary business, we should conduct our proceedings orderly. The question really is whether the supplementary questions by Mr Chiam are properly put. Standing Orders No. 18 says:

    '(1) Questions may be put to Ministers relating to -

    (a) affairs within their official functions; or

    (b) Bills, motion or other public matters connected with the business of Parliament for which such Ministers are responsible.'

    Mr Chiam maintains that the PCF kindergartens are under the charge of the Minister for Education solely by reason of the fact that the Ministry approves and registers them. Supposing there is a kindergarten run by the YMCA in Potong Pasir. It is approved by the Ministry of Education.
